channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Dozens Killed in Suicide Attack on Shiite Shrine North of Baghdad
item.description: Three suicide bombers disguised in military uniforms infiltrated a mausoleum, the Iraqi authorities said, killing at least 36 people and wounding 40.
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY

item.title: Memo From Britain: British Politics Gives a Sense of Government by Old School Chums
item.media:description: David Cameron, left, and Michael Gove in 2010. After taking opposite sides on the “Brexit” issue, the two old friends are reportedly no longer speaking.
item.description: It’s hard not to conclude that Britain’s path into crisis has largely been determined by an elite clique of people plotting with and scheming against one another.
item.dc:creator: SARAH LYALL

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: May and Leadsom Face Off to Become Prime Minister
item.media:description: A view of the City of London, the financial heart of Britain.
item.description: The next premier will be a woman, consumer confidence has tanked and the trans-Atlantic alliance may be facing its most important moment since the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: ‘Racist’ Killing of Nigerian Asylum Seeker Stuns and Saddens Italy
item.media:description: From left, Mara Di Lullo, the prefect of Fermo; Angelino Alfano, the Italian interior minister; and Domenico Seccia, the prosecutor in Fermo, spoke on Thursday about the death of Emmanuel Chidi Namdi, a Nigerian who died after what the authorities believe was a racially motivated attack.
item.description: The victim and his wife, who were assaulted by a man hurling racist abuse, had fled to Italy to escape the extremist group Boko Haram, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Mayor Fluent in Twitter Embodies a New Canadian Diversity
item.media:description: “My mouth still gets me into trouble once in a while.” NAHEED NENSHI
item.media:credit: Todd Korol/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.description: Naheed Nenshi, the groundbreaking Muslim mayor of Calgary, is known for his acid Twitter retorts and for revitalizing the city. His faith rarely comes up.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Eduardo Cunha, Who Helped Oust Dilma Rousseff, Resigns Brazil House Post
item.media:description: Eduardo Cunha, the former speaker of the lower house of Congress, arrived for a news in Brasília on Thursday.
item.description: Mr. Cunha, the speaker of the lower house, stepped down as indignation mounted over his quest to remain in power while facing bribery charges.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: For China, a Missile Defense System in South Korea Spells a Failed Courtship
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea in Beijing in 2013.
item.description: South Korea showed that it was embracing its alliance with Washington more than ever, and that it would rely less on China to keep North Korea at bay.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Widespread Flooding in China Kills Nearly 200, Providing a Test for Leaders
item.description: The country’s flood defenses have faltered in the past, but Prime Minister Li Keqiang has said that the government is better prepared this year.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Amid Political Uncertainty, Australia Faces Ratings Downgrade
item.media:description: Malcolm Turnbull, the prime minister of Australia. The inconclusive results of the election on Saturday left no clear winner to grapple with the country’s budget issues.
item.description: Standard & Poor’s warned that it could lower Australia’s gilt-edged triple-A credit rating in the next two years in light of an inconclusive election.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies

item.title: Sinosphere: In China, Relatives Await Word on Detained Rights Lawyers After a Year
item.media:description: The wives of human rights lawyers who were detained a year ago wore dresses with their husbands’ names to the state prosecutor’s offices in Beijing on Monday.
item.description: Nearly 250 human rights lawyers and activists were detained last year, and this week loved ones of those still in custody began to speak out more vocally.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Typhoon Nepartak Heads for China After Killing 2 in Taiwan
item.media:description: A street in Taitung, Taiwan, on Friday after Typhoon Nepartak tore through.
item.description: The storm hit Taiwan as a Category 4 typhoon, the second-most powerful category, with wind gusts reaching 140 miles per hour.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Taiwan Train Explosion Wasn’t Organized Terrorism, Government Says
item.media:description: A bomb squad officer entering the commuter train where a bombing occurred on Thursday. The episode is likely to revive concerns about security on public transportation in Taiwan.
item.description: At least 25 people were injured in the blast, which Taiwan’s premier said was most likely the work of “an individual person.” A news agency said a suspect had been identified.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: South Korea and U.S. Agree to Deploy Missile Defense System
item.media:description: Yoo Jeh-seung, center, the deputy minister for policy for the South Korean Defense Ministry, with Lt. Gen. Thomas Vandal, the commander of United States Eighth Army in South Korea, in Seoul, the capital, on Friday.
item.description: The announcement came despite strong protests from China, which sees the plan as a threat to its own security.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Transfer Policy Questioned After Former Guantánamo Bay Detainee Goes Missing
item.description: A House committee grills Obama administration officials when Uruguay loses track of a Syrian who had been resettled there after his release from prison at the U.S. naval base in Cuba.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Growing Unease as British Mutual Funds Block the Exit Doors
item.media:description: The financial district of Canary Wharf in London. British fund companies are ready to take drastic steps to prevent investors from leaving their funds.
item.media:credit: Marco Kesseler for The New York Times
item.description: The refusal of six asset management firms to allow investor withdrawals is creating a nightmare situation for global markets.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.

item.title: Deutsche Bank Pulls Back from Deals in Coal Mining Sector
item.media:description: A Blackhawk Mining coal tower in Kentucky. In recent years, Deutsche has assisted Blackhawk, which has been snapping up some of the best mines of bankrupt or nearly bankrupt companies such as Patriot Coal and Arch Coal.
item.description: Investment bankers leave as Deutsche joins other banks in cutting financing to a beaten-down industry that has attracted environmentalists’ scorn.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL CORKERY and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Iraq Report Prompts More Defensiveness Than Regret From Tony Blair
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain acknowledged failings with “more sorrow, regret and apology and in greater measure than you can know” in London on Wednesday, after the release of the official report on Britain’s conduct of the Iraq war.
item.description: An exhaustive study of how Britain went to war in 2003 led to soul searching by the former prime minister, but no acknowledgment that he got it wrong.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Two Convicted of Conspiring to Leak Vatican Secrets in ‘Vatileaks 2’
item.media:description: Francesca Immacolata Chaouqui, a public relations specialist, spoke to reporters on Thursday after a Vatican court convicted her for conspiring to leak confidential information.
item.description: A Vatican court found two former members of a papal oversight commission guilty, but said it could not try two journalists.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Eight U.S. Airlines Win Tentative Approval to Fly to Havana
item.media:description: José Martí International Airport in Havana, Cuba’s capital. American tourism to Cuba is still technically prohibited, but the federal government in March relaxed some travel restrictions.
item.description: American Airlines, Alaska Airlines and Delta Air Lines are among those that received preliminary approval for flights that could begin in September.
item.dc:creator: ANNALYN KURTZ

item.title: Germany Passes ‘No Means No’ Law After Cologne Attacks
item.media:description: A demonstration in Berlin against sexual violence last month. Women’s rights groups and opposition lawmakers had lobbied for two years for the principle of “no means no” to be adopted in their country.
item.media:credit: Jorg Carstensen/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The legislation would make it possible to prosecute in cases where victims made clear they did not want to engage in sexual activity, even if they did not cry out for help.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Letter From Europe: Europe Turns Inward, Just as Challenges on Its Borders Mount
item.media:description: Banners of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and other leaders of Turkey outside a Ramadan dinner organized by his Justice and Development Party in Istanbul last month. The country is waging a campaign against Kurdish separatists.
item.description: If Middle Eastern countries fear infection from Syria’s civil war, so do many European countries fear infection by the British vote to leave their union.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Race for Britain’s Prime Minister Down to Theresa May and Andrea Leadsom
item.media:description: Theresa May, left, the home secretary, and Andrea Leadsom, an energy minister, are the remaining Conservative Party candidates in Britain.
item.description: Ms. May, the home secretary, or Ms. Leadsom, an energy minister, will become the first woman to lead Britain since Margaret Thatcher resigned in 1990.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: ‘Brexit’ and Russia Loom Over Obama’s Final NATO Summit Meeting
item.media:description: President Obama boarding Air Force One at Joint Base Andrews, Md., on Thursday en route to the NATO summit meeting in Warsaw.
item.description: The meeting will take place amid tumult including Russian aggression in Eastern Europe and disarray since Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Denmark’s Tougher Citizenship Test Stumps Even Its Natives
item.media:description: A restaurant in Copenhagen. The Danish integration minister said that 68.8 percent of foreigners who took a citizenship test in June had failed it.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: The government, which has been tightening rules on immigration, has made little effort to hide the goal of the exam: to make it significantly harder to become Danish.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Sinosphere: China to Pillory, or Praise, Cities Based on Water Pollution
item.media:description: A pipe discharging wastewater into the Yangtze River from a paper mill in Anqing, Anhui Province.
item.description: The Ministry of Environmental Protection has said it plans to monitor supplies in 338 cities and each month name the 10 best and 10 worst.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Conservatives Decide a Woman Should Lead Britain
item.media:description: Outside Parliament Square in central London on Saturday.
item.description: Tory lawmakers have chosen Theresa May and Andrea Leadsom as finalists who will go before the party’s rank-and-file members to become its next leader, as well as prime minister.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: Bombing at Bangladesh’s Largest Eid Gathering Kills at Least 3
item.media:description: Police officers during a bomb attack in the Kishoreganj district of Bangladesh on Thursday.
item.description: The Islamic State had warned that more violence would follow the militants’ bloody siege in Dhaka, the capital, last week.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Danone of France to Buy WhiteWave in $10 Billion Deal to Bolster U.S. Portfolio
item.media:description: An organic dairy farm in Brookfield, Vt., supplies Horizon Organic milk for the WhiteWave Foods Company.
item.media:credit: Caleb Kenna for The New York Times
item.description: The agreement values WhiteWave at $12.5 billion and would increase Danone’s offerings of organic products and plant-based alternatives to milk and yogurt.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE STROM

item.title: In Shadow of ‘Brexit,’ NATO Will Sound Message of Unity Against Russia
item.media:description: American and Polish airborne troops during a NATO exercise last month near Torun, Poland.
item.description: The multinational group is poised to agree to add four battalions along the eastern front in answer to an increasingly aggressive Russian leadership.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Sinosphere: China Violated Rights of Detained American, U.N. Panel Says
item.media:description: Phan Phan-Gillis, an American business consultant who has been detained in China for more than a year.
item.description: A rights advocacy group highlighted that view as it sought to put more pressure on China during a visit by the United Nations leader in Beijing this week.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: A Ukrainian Kleptocrat Wants His Money and U.S. Asylum
item.media:description: Pavlo Lazarenko, left, the former prime minister of Ukraine, with his son, Olexander Lazarenko, in 2004.
item.description: Pavlo Lazarenko, felon and former prime minister of Ukraine, is battling the United States for $250 million held offshore and for political asylum.
item.dc:creator: LESLIE WAYNE

item.title: Ruling on South China Sea Nears in a Case Beijing Has Tried to Ignore
item.media:description: A frigate for the Chinese Navy patrolling near the Spratly Islands, in the South China Sea, in March. For more than three years, Beijing has refused to participate in the proceedings of an international tribunal considering a challenge to its expansive claims in the waters.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: China has rejected the work of an international tribunal considering its claims in the South China Sea. But with a decision expected soon, it seems to be getting nervous.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: What in the World: A Fire Monkey Can Usher In Chaos. So Can 600 or So Macaques.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photo by Ben Sklar for The New York Times, Eric Thayer/Reuters
item.description: This is a rare Year of the Fire Monkey, an occasion often associated with chaos. Just ask a village in China that’s been overrun by little, loud primates.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: Bulgarians Hope Che Guevara and Brigitte Bardot Can Save Their Village
item.media:description: Stefana Gospodinova and her mule with murals of themselves and Brigitte Bardot, a well-known animal lover, in the Bulgarian village of Staro Zhelezare.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Two artists want their murals of famous people — alongside portraits of residents — to help start a revival in Staro Zhelezare, population 400.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: What in the World: Why Finland’s Newborns Sleep in Cardboard Cribs
item.media:description: A baby in the Kela maternity package box, which is distributed to new parents in Finland.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: “Baby boxes” were introduced in the 1930s to ensure that every infant had a safe place to nap (and that Mom got a checkup). And they worked.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Editorial: Iraq War Lies, 13 Years Later
item.media:description: Tony Blair at a press conference in London on Wednesday.
item.description: An official British report has reminded both Britons and Americans how lies and ideology can lead nations into war.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on the Dallas Shooting
item.description: Uncle Sam pleads for calm.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Frexit? Dexit? Auxit? No Way. Britain Is Special.
item.media:description: Revelers sang the national anthem during Queen Elizabeth II’s 90th birthday celebrations in London last month.
item.description: The island and the Continent have a long, rocky — and unique — history.
item.dc:creator: ALINA POLYAKOVA and NEIL FLIGSTEIN

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
